docs.lead_paragraph: Abortion The candidates all profess opposition to abortion rights, but there are distinctions. Several have signed a pledge that requires appointment only of those with anti-abortion views to key government posts. Others have declined. Some favor allowing abortion in cases of rape and incest.

docs.lead_paragraph: Management, saying the real estate market is suffering, is seeking givebacks in a four-year agreement with Local 32BJ, whose members make about $49,000 a year.

headline.seo: Contract Deadline Nears for 22,000 New York City Office Cleaners
headline.main: Contract Deadline Nears for 22,000 Office Cleaners in City
headline.print_headline: Contract Deadline Nears for 22,000 Office Cleaners in City

docs.abstract: Owners of 1,500 office towers in New York City are preparing for possible January 1 strike by members of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, which represents 22,000 building cleaners; workers, whose contract is about to expire, are striking in response to two-tier wage system and cuts to health benefits proposed by owners; two sides appear likely to come to agreement on new contract by or shortly after deadline.
docs.snippet: Management, saying the real estate market is suffering, is seeking givebacks in a four-year agreement with Local 32BJ, whose members make about $49,000 a year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Roman Catholic bishops see a fight over adoption rules in Illinois as part of an escalating campaign by the government to trample on their religious freedom.

headline.main: Bishops Say Rules on Gay Parents Limit Freedom of Religion
headline.print_headline: Illinois Bishops Drop Program Over Bias Rule

docs.abstract: Roman Catholic bishops in Illinois have closed most of the Catholic Charities affiliates in the state rather than comply with requirement that they must consider same-sex couples as potential foster-care and adoptive parents to receive state money; view law as part of an escalating campaign by the government to trample on their religious freedom.
docs.snippet: Roman Catholic bishops see a fight over adoption rules in Illinois as part of an escalating campaign by the government to trample on their religious freedom.
